This place is a true neighborhood special. It's cute and small, totally reasonable on prices and the food is simple but solidly delicious. Add in specials like half bottles on Wednesdays and you have the perfect trifecta + 1! 

Carciofini Ripieni - I get this appetizer all the time. Artichokes stuffed with goat cheese, wrapped in prosciutto and covered in pesto served with a greens. This is an amazing starter and is lighter and more delicate than it sounds.

The pasta here is freshly made and delicious. The Spaghetti alla Puttanesca's sauce is delicious with a great salty briney flavor coming from the capers and anchovies in it. Add meatballs and this is fantastic (their meatballs are very flavorful).

Gnocchi alla Boscaiola - the gnocchi is delicate and pillowy - made to perfection. This dish with truffle oil sausage and mushrooms is lovely. While truffles are delicious, the quantity of truffle oil is just a tad overpowering but the dish overall is still very good.

Pizza Cappricciosa - The pizza crust is crunchy thin Neapolitan style. The toppings on this pizza - prosciutto, egg, mushrooms, artichoke and mozzarella are lovely accompaniments but I think the composition is a little lacking. Everything slides off the crust a little too easily. Be forewarned as well, only half your pizza will contain prosciutto and half will contain the artichoke and egg. Not sure why the whole pizza isn't covered with all toppings.

A side of broccoli rabbe provides some greens to accompany your pasta - tasty but be forewarned, very overpowering on the garlic however expertly cooked al dente.

This restaurant also stays open until 10pm which is nice because many places around here close at 9 or 9:30. This place is definitely a favorite that I plan to continue returning to.
author: Steven H.

description: I have been meaning to write a review for this place for so long now. I absolutely love this place. It is very dark inside and intimate, and loud at the same time, but the food is a MUST HAVE! I am vegetarian, and just the quality and freshness of the food is great! You can actually taste each topping on the pizza, and every ingredient in the pastas. My boyfriend is a carnivore, and he has loved everything there also. The service is great. My boyfriend and I seem to always have the tall gentlemen who makes us feel so comfortable and welcome. I would pick this place to eat for my last meal. Love Love LOVE!!
author: Crystal D.

description: This place has grown on me and earned five stars. The pizza and pasta are consistently good. The pizza crust is cracker thin and crispy - my fav! The service has always been friendly and welcoming. Best of all, the prices are very reasonable. Overall a really nice neighborhood stop for dinner.
author: Brad B.

description:
After our last foray to Vega which was so horrible we thought, ok, let's be kind, perhaps it was a bad night, we went again.

It was worse!

First . . .hello owner, you might want to be minding the shop. 

Bread wasn't baked all the way through and waitress got snippy about it.

The broccolini side was delivered to us with cold spots among the tepid spots which means they took it from the fridge to reheat!    And it was stemmy and the greens were bitter.  We sent it back.  What came back was the same bitter mess, but slightly warmer.  

We ordered a 2nd round of wine and the glass was less full - retaliation from wait person?  Most likely.

Saw a sign on the door for bambini night . . . .1/2 of pizza if you bring kids.  WTF?  We hard working adults pay full price?  This is age discrimination and I don't like it.

When they first took over Valentina's it was very good, now it's descended so far into hell there is no return and I'll not go back to see if it's resurrected - I've given them too many tries, they've gotten too much of my recession money.  No more.  Let the bambinos take this place over!
author: Cinnamon Z.

description:
Pizza's were solid, and this place was booked and was very busy.

I also tried their CAPELLINI AL GRANCHIO, and I wasn't that impressed. I think it was because of their pasta they used. i'm a thick pasta type of guy, thin pasta was used Also their lobster, perhaps they could add a little more :)

This is a hidden gem in Bernal Heights. If you're there, you should try it out, but make sure to make reservations
author: Eric A.

description:
I'm just giving them 1 star because I can't proceed with this review not clicking on any stars, but my real score is -10!

We actually had reservations for my birthday for 6 on a Saturday night at Vega, which is across the street from Liberty Café.  I chose this place after seeing it on Bay Area Check Please.  Since it was my bday, my husband actually emailed to confirm the night before with the owner, no less.  We show up and they don't have our reservations! The blond waitress there was extremely rude, didn't bother to try to figure out what might have happened or contact the owner (who wasn't there) and treated my husband like he made the mistake, asking him, very condescendingly, if he was sure he had the right date .  Sadly, my husband had deleted the email exchange with the owner so he couldn't pull it up to show the blond.  So we decided to find another spot to eat and there was Liberty Café!  Besides, who would want to patronize a place where your first point of contact is rude and condescending?!  Sidenote: My husband did email the owner back the next day and she was very apologetic.  She knew exactly who he was talking about(probably the same one referenced in the other reviews for bad service), which I thought was interesting.  To me, it seems that she knows she has a problem employee, but tolerates it which blows my mind.  The owner also offered us a gift certificate for our troubles, but that was two weeks ago and nothing's arrived in the mail so I'm not holding my breath. 

From the street, Liberty Cafe looked like they were almost full, so my husband went inside, explained what had happened across the street and they were more than willing to accommodate us if we were willing to sit in their back cottage!  You wouldn't know it from the street, but not only is there a back cottage, but there's also an outdoor patio(w/heat lamps) and a movie playing!  It was so cute.  We ended up in the cottage which was really cute and cozy.  Food was delicious and fresh.  The only thing is the portions did seem small, but at the end of the meal it worked out because we ended up having room for 2 desserts (to share).  

It seemed like a real neighborhood restaurant with lots of local regulars.  I would definitely come back and check out their movie nights with my kids.  

But most of all, the customer service was fantastic.  They were so great and accommodating especially when we had such a horrible start to my bday dinner.  Thank you, Liberty Café! 4.5 Stars!
author: RL P.

description:
Delightful.  I wished I could have eaten more of each dish we had.  The service was accomodating and warm, and the owner attentive and personal.  Portions are quite sufficient and filling.  Will be back for more. :D

Items to order--
# Insalata ricca
# Gnocchi alla boscaiola
# Spaghetti alla carbonara
# Roasted polenta w/ melted fontina cheese
# Flourless chocolate cake
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Great great pasta.  They don't have the spaghetti carbonara on the menu anymore, but it was divine and so well priced.
author: Tom P.

description:
Here's the story:  it may look the same, but Valentina was recently taken over by the owners of Vino Rosso Wine Bar, and is now called Vega.

And oh, what a difference some critical changes can make.

First of all, the food is much improved, and much more consistent.  

They offer several varieties of thin-crust pizza, which is such a welcome thing in a neighborhood sadly lacking in pizza options.  Our favorites are the Margherita and the Mushroom Truffle Oil.

Secondly, there is an entire section on gnocchi.  And they have truly nailed the texture of this hard-to-master pasta, which is so hard to do - not too mushy, not too springy, not too heavy, not too light.  They know this, so they offer it in several different ways - with your choice of 4 sauces, or in a heartier main dish.  We had the Gnocchi with sausage with mushrooms in a truffle oil cream sauce and it was the best dish of the night, by far.

The protein based dishes are good as well.  We had a mediterranean-inspired cod that was well cooked and flavored with tomatoes, capers, and olives - very bright and fresh, and a nice contrast to the carb-loaded pastas and pizzas.

Service was very nice and accommodating - we mentioned that we had limited time and the food came out quickly, so we didn't feel rushed at all.  Next time, I will try one of the wines from their extensive list.

A nice makeover for the neighborhood's restaurant community, and the packed tables attest to its success thus far.  And talk about knowing your customers - they now offer a Pizza Bambino night on Tuesdays, when you can get half price pizzas if you bring your kids.

I will be back soon, and often - bravo, Vega!
author: Liz S.

description:
The food is VERY disappointing, NOTHING like Valentina's.  Valentina's was my favorite italian restaurant in the city.  This was a nicely decorated Pasta Pomodoro. 

The stars are for the wine which was very good.

I won't be back.
author: Addrianna R.

description:
Came here with reservations, but still had to wait at least half an hour. If I were hungry, I'd have been upset...

I tried the Capellini al grancho, pizza bresaola & rhugetta, and a side of sauteed spinach. The pasta was decent, but I'd have preferred it with thick noodles, like papardelle? rather than the thin noodles that tasted like asian noodles.

Pizza, on the other hand was insanely good. SO GOOD. I want to try every pizza here. Side of spinach was good, humongo serving.

I will come back here for the pizza!
author: Carol L.

description:
4.5 stars

Vega has one of the best pizzas in SF, and reminds me of Delfina - both have delicately thin-crusted pizza with extra fresh tomato base and mozzarella, except it is more:
+ cozy candlelit atmosphere
- minus hipsters
+ old neighbors and families 
- crazy lines

They also have an amazing lamb, nice grilled calamari, and pizza with an egg which surprisingly works!

I'm a huge fan. Will definitely return!
author: V W.

description:
If I could do half stars, I give this 4 & a half...closer to 5 even.

Our night started off with great service - knowledgeable and friendly. The food was FAB - all four of us love our apps & entrees. Very generous portions, very reasonable prices. We liked the wine list too. So glad to be introduced to this place....we'll be back. And...we anticipated difficult parking, but it was actually quite easy, even right at dinner time. I agree with the others...very yummy ice cream sandwich - great thin crust pizza - dee-lish gnocchi... ... ... ...
author: K. D.

description:
After my first meal (of what will be many more) at Vega (formerly Valentina), the word that comes to mind is chiarascuro, the perfect balance of light and dark.

The ambiance: deep red-painted walls, romantic low light, bare dark wood tables, and inviting, flickering white candles.  

The wine: an effervescent Prosecco to the most sultry of reds.  In unsophisticated wine-ese I asked owner Vega for a "dark red" wine and she brought a warm, deep burgundy Italian vintage (none of these thin, sour California reds that look like cranberry juice, thank you very much) that held its own against the earthy mushrooms to come.

The food: rich, hearty flavors contrasting with the lightest of textures, simply and freshly prepared.

To start, creamy mushroom soup with truffle oil and parmeggiano cheese -- a rich, intensely mushroom-flavored divinity, made sinfully creamy, incredibly, with mostly potatoes and very little actual cream.  The truffle oil just enough to cause salivation without overpowering.

Broccoli rabe -- a plate of the darkest, freshest greens simply prepared with olive oil.

Quattro formaggio pizza -- an almost liquid blend of cheeses like I remember from Italy, featuring gorgonzola and pears, on the lightest, thinnest and crispiest of crusts.  In my greed I almost wished for more thin, sweet slices of pear to contrast the strong, salty cheeses.

And then the gnocchi.  Oh, the gnocchi.  Little pillowy clouds resting in more creamy, mushroomy goodness with more truffle oil, but with a distinctly different flavor from the soup, owing to the bright, almost citrus-y white wine in the sauce.  Not a gluey, starchy potato glob in sight; really the most perfect gnocchi I've had.

And just when we thought another bite couldn't be consumed, the panne cotta: fluffy, white, lighter than air, with dark red strawberry sauce (but not too much, and not too sweet) drizzled over top.

A place you could ensconce yourself and a few friends or a special someone for an entire evening, slowly savoring a dish from each section of the menu, expertly paired with Italian wine.

Brava, Vega.

(Also posted on Valentina's Yelp page.)
author: Maggie T.

description:
It pains me when I discover a pizza I do not love, and unfortunately, Vega's fare caused great distress.  

Let me assure you that the quality of their ingredients, the service of the waitresses, and decor of the restaurant were above average, and not in question here.  I simply could not bring myself to appreciate their interpretation of thin-crust pizza.

We ordered the CALAMARI E CANNELLINI appetizer and PIZZA  CAPRICCIOSA, PIZZA BROCCOLI & SALSICCIA, and PIZZA SPECK & BUFALA pies.  The calamari appetizer was flavorful, but not a dish I would order again.  The pizzas all came uncut, with toppings unevenly distributed, and on a saltine-cracker-thin crust.  If you are thinking that I am an uncultured San Franciscan, and that I have just described the essence of San Francisco pizzas, the rest of my review will be of little interest to you.

The uncut pizzas made them difficult to share, and when we tried to cut our own slices, the cracker-thin crust crumbled in protest and to our dismay.  The uneven distribution (huge chunks of prosciutto on one-fourth of the pizza, having two slices without tasting artichoke hearts, etc.) made sharing the pizzas and enjoying each slice equally a chore too.  

The crust was the greatest disappointment for me.  The edges were burnt, and the thinness and crunch of each bite caused me to wonder if I could have been equally satisfied staying at home with a box of saltine crackers, cheese, and prosciutto.

Once again, this review is not a reflection of the quality of the restaurant, but their interpretation of thin-crust pizza and my personal pizza preference.
author: Andrew M.

description:
Cozy Comfort Food

Yuuuuuum! Dinner at Vega is delish if you know what to get. There are a couple of things on the menu that don't shine as much as others. We love the pizza with egg and baked rigatoni. Specials are usually sensational. Service can be slow and cozy also translates to cramped. But this little nook feels like New York, so fagedaboudit.
author: Maria G.

description:
This is my go to restaurant for all occasions. I've taken my mom, my boyfriend, my best friends, and new friends here for dinner.  Everything I've tried here is great, but my favorites are the minestrone and the baked rigatoni.  

The staff here is a real class act. The restaurant is perfectly lit, facing adorable Cortland street. If they can't seat you right away, consider grabbing a drink at Liberty Cafe's hidden bar in the back while you wait.

Wednesday's is half off on all bottles of wine!
author: Anne H.

description: Delicious. The Costolette di Maiale al sugo (Berkshire pork ribs slow cooked in tomato sauce served with polenta) was amazing. Two separate people stopped by our outdoor table to ask what it was, it looked so good (and it was).  My partner had the fish of the day (sea bass) which was very tasty as well.  The capellini with Dungeness crab was pretty good too.  Did not try the pizza. A very pleasant evening.
author: Buttonwillow M.

description: party of four [girls night out] went for early dinner on a saturday night.  we made reservations online [very easy] at 5 p.m.  best time to go to beat the rush.  we ordered a pizza for appetizer followed by sharing two different salads. all organic.  we each ordered a pasta dish and ended our meal with panna cotta and tiramisu for dessert to shared.  everything was delish.  the restaurant is small and intimate.  service was excellent and our meal was timed perfectly from kitchen to table.  great experience for eating and conversation.
author: R L.

description:
Vega has finally come into it's own. I resisted reviewing our first meal (shortly after they opened ... let's pretend that never happened).  Now everything we have tried so far is fantastic, and this restaurant (formerly Valentina's) is back in the regular rotation.
The pizza's are thin, puffy and yummy. The pastas are delicious (don't miss the gnocchi).  We haven't tried the meat dishes yet, but I you can rest assured that we will be back many times and the menu will become as much an old friend as Valentina's.
author: John K.

description:
had been wanting to check this joint out since it opened.  finally got me a girlfriend and a babysitter and made it happen.  

the lighting was great.  nice and dark but bright enough to see your food.  the waitress was attentive as well.  the vino came quickly.  (so many choices)  parking is ridiculous on a fri nite  luckily someone was leaving as we were arriving.  no suit and tie required but spiffin it up one time dont hurt either...

the food was belisimo!  kinda skimped me on the carpaccio but it was good..and it did say thinly sliced...but it was see-through
rigatoni was cheesy and was a huge portion...the capellini and dungeness crab was so good...the crab was plentiful and fresh with a good amount of citrus and alfredo sauce was super creamy...

kinda pricey but mos def goin back...
author: Bane V.

description:
Tried this place for the first time last week...

Let me start with the negatives..... The waitress was kind of annoying.... Seemed like she didn't wanted to be there.. She only got excited when she dropped the bill off. Also, there was a kid screaming and playing with toys and the mother was in la la land and had no clue.... I don't hold that against the restaurant.

That being said, I want to come back here.... They have many pizzas..... a few entrees.. salads and sides..

We tried the chicken.. which was great... yummy sauce.... and a pizza... which was solid....

The place is very small.... We got there early, around 6pm, and got a spot...

Overall, a good meal.... I hope this place does well...
author: Joe B.

description:
What a nice little restaurant. Starting with the decor, you will immediately notice how nice this place is looking from the outside in. Once inside, this little restaurant has a warm romantic feel. 

The staff is very friendly and attentive. Serving bread and oil as they take your drink order. 

The food was excellent. Staring with aps, we ordered the calamari. When it came out I realized it wasn't fried. It was sauteed in a vinegar type base. It was the best non-fried calamari I've ever tasted. For dinner, I ordered the Rigatoni with meatballs. It was baked with the perfect amount of meatballs and cheese. My wife order a pizza, which we shared, and it was very tasty. For dessert, the tiramisu and an orange flan.  Both were excellent.

We had a total of 6 people in our group, and had reservations. The table was ready when we got there, and is highly recommended because the place is small and you'll definitely avoid a wait during the busy dinner hour. 

Lastly, they offer a huge wine list to go with your dinner. 

We'll definitely be back to try another pasta dish and pizza.
author: Eric D.

description:
Oh wow, such high hopes for Vega after seeing them on Check Please.  We were so excited to eat here, but unfortunately we won't be back.  Everything started great, the service throughout the night was very good, and our party of 4 split a Pizza Margherita and the calamari.  Those were excellent, the pizza was superb, nice flavors, perfect crust, and the calamari was soft and tender (not chewy) and had a beautiful acidity to it.  
It was Wednesday so we took advantage of the half priced wine night, having a bottle of Prosecco to start, which was served at room temp and dumped in a bucked of cold water, but our first glasses were slightly chilled at best.  We were somewhat disappointed by the wine list, as there was a huge hole between $40 and $90, but we went with the Cannonau, which was a good choice.
My main course was great, I had the baked rigatoni with meatballs, it was a huge serving, and was the best dish at our table.  Our gripe really stemmed from the Gnocchi alla boscaiola that is served with a "touch" of truffle oil.  I love truffles, who doesn't, but this seemed like it was served with a cup of truffle oil.  The smell was overwhelming, and the astringency and strength was burned into my mouth until this morning (yes, I did brush my teeth).  I would call this at the point of inedible, and it nearly ruined the meal.  
We got the check and after two bottles of wine we were still in a festive mood, except all of us were a bit annoyed that no one was even close on the guess the check game.  We were all under by a lot, I missed by about $75.  I hate to lose, so I grabbed my Iphone and added up the bill.  I did it again before announcing to the table that the total on the bill was $85 more than it should have been.  After a quick apology they fixed this, but what if we would have just paid and not even checked.  I'm sorry but this mistake is inexcusable and will be the lasting impression we will have about this restaurant.

Sorry Vega, I wanted to love you, but you didn't meet the standards with the food, then you tried to take my money...  Better Italian can be had elsewhere.
author: Jonathan U.

description:
Love love love this place. 

Be forewarned: these are BIG portions.  One salad, one pizza, and one pasta literally wiped out my husband and me for the night.  For some reason we had these grand ideas of visiting the gym after Vega...that definitely didn't happen. 

We got the house salad, which was enormous and absolutely delicious: big chunks of grapefruit, fresh greens, sharp cheese, and a light dressing.  We moved on next to a braesola pizza with arugula, and as other folks have mentioned here, the crust is great. 

By this time, I was full.  But we wanted to try a range of things, so we also went for the Cacio e Pepe pasta, thinking "Oh, pasta with a little cheese; sounds light!"  This pasta was absolutely amazing - but decidedly not light. There's so much Cacio cheese on the pasta that it turns into an almost cream sauce, to which the sharp pepper is a perfect complement.  We've been trying to recreate this dish at home ever since, but still haven't come close to Vega's.  It was the best thing I had eaten in quite some time. 

All in all, you feel like you're eating in someone's home at Vega. The owner was incredibly nice, just attentive enough, and the food was outstanding.  Can't wait to go back and get a whole plate of Cacio e Pepe for myself!
author: Anne D.

description:
Parking here is tight...so practice your parking patience...


But what a sexy place to have a comforting Italian dinner. Yah, I said sexy... 

The intimate size of Vega is good for date night, or even double-date night. Dining here is like having a dinner party at your closest Italian buddy's home...only you don't know anyone else around you and you can hear their conversation.
 
The "hostess" was a bit unnerving, aka jumpy. I think she might have been new. Her attentiveness vs. dining room square footage ratio was suffocating.   This was my "pit" of the night.

I can't remember the actual names of what we ordered, so I'll just describe... 

The polenta crab cakes were surprisingly tasty. I was a little bit put off by the brick-like presentation complemented with 2 grapefruit wedges (garnish or a side-to-my-side?). But put a fork in it...it's good. 

Previous yelpers suggested the Gnocchi. Can we rename this the OHMIGAWDGNOCCHI!!! Pillows of creamy goodness melting in your mouth.  This was my "peak" for the night.

I'd definitely go back and bring a couple more friends...
author: Rochelle D.

description:
Exceeded our expectations!

We were originally going to go to another restaurant but it wasn't open so we decided to pick a restaurant at random and go with it.  We're so happy we picked this place!

The owners are Italian!  And very sweet.  The food was very solid.  I got the gnocci and it was so, so good!  Next time I'm in Bernal Heights will def go back to this place!
author: Nancy C.

description:
We had an incredibly enjoyable night here this week for a big celebration. We pre ordered for a large party who admittedly took up half the place. Food came well timed all evening and the servers are very friendly and attentive.

The wine list is not so pocket friendly but has some incredibly delicious wines at good prices, just not lower end so much. Excellent prosecco and many great italian reds, well chosen and hard to fault, looking forward to more chances to try the rest of the reds on the menu soon!

The salads are excellent, perfectly dressed walnut spinach salad and a very tasty pear salad. I'm not much of a gnocchi fan admittedly but we had three excellent versions at Vega, they were incredibly soft and pillowy, great flavor and texture was insanely good. Maybe I like good gnocchi after all.

Lamb chops were delicious, I'm picky about lamb but nothing to say except delicious, the polenta was close to perfect too, add mushrooms and you can't really beat that.  Can't recall the chicken dish we shared but that too was very well prepared, juicy and tasty and addictive.

I'm serious about this place, it was off the chain good. One of the best meals I've had in a while, thank you Vega & Giuseppe for a fantastic restaurant and and an amazing night.
author: Steve S.

description:
This place is totally delicious and it's a fantastic neighborhood gem. 

Do try their gnocchi, especially those with the truffle oil... they are amazing and the best gnocchi in the Bay Area hands down (and I am from the land of gnocchi!). 

The restaurant is family owned by Giuseppe from Rome and Vega his wife, the same couple that owns VinoRosso a block down on Cortland. They put their heart in the food, the menu and the whole package.... you will feel like you are in Italy, especially after you try some of Giuseppe's special recipes! Vega is very knowledgeable about the wines and this is a great combo. 

I know they had some hiccups with some of the service staff in the past and they did their best to make it work and got over the issues. My friends and I never had any issues with the service: it is what you would expect from a well priced neighborhood restaurant.... and most times better than expensive well-known establishments: we never missed our water, our order is always correct, the servers have been attentive to ask if we want more wine, etc. 

The atmosphere is warm, cozy, and lively at the same time. The menu has some great options for everybody, even though I haven't tried the meat and fish dishes yet and I historically have stuck to my favorites: the apps, the salads, the first dishes (pastas, gnocchi, etc) and the pizza. 

Another positive note is the wine list: because they also own VinoRosso, the wine bar, they offer a great list of wines by the glass and by the bottle.... and best of all, it's extremely well priced! A great value. 

A note on the PIZZA: delicious. The crust is thin and a little more crispy than other Roman/Neapolitan pizzerias, but so tasty! The dough is not too salty either, so you won't be dying of thirst later in the evening, like with other pizzas! The best part is that they use only very fresh ingredients, mostly all from the Farmers' Market, and thus usually have a special pizza based on what is fresh. The other day I had it with fresh cherry tomatoes, mozzarella di buffala, and SQUASH BLOSSOMS! YUM!!

When my friends ask me where I find my favorite Italian food in the city (they ask because I am from Italy) I always tell them to try Vega.  Can't wait to go back!

*FOOD: amazing
*SERVICE: good, friendly
*ATMOSPHERE: very cozy and nice. Romantic too.
*WINE: great list
*PRICES/VALUE: extremely well prices wine list and menu. Great value!
*BEST FOR: casual but delicious dinner (accompanied by a glass of wine) with friends or with significant other.
author: OcchiDiGatto S.

description:
I REALLY enjoyed my meal at Vega.  A good friend of mine who used to own an Italian restaurant took us there.  His selections are always excellent cuisine and Vega was no exception.

My meal was absolutely fantastic.  My appetizer was sauteed calamari that was wonderful.  Not over cooked and a nice Mediterranean mixture of spices.  My main course was a baked white fish over a bed of pureed cauliflower and potatoes, a unique and delightful combination.  We were all too full for desert but the desert menu was appealing.  

The other two people in our party also loved their meals.  I give it 5 stars because of the food.  It s a small restaurant and the ambiance is of a neighborhood restaurant and not a 5 star restaurant.  The service was fine and the ambiance did not detract from the wonderful meal.
author: Steve P.

description: So intimate and romantic. Great staff, great atmosphere, great food. We had the mussels and the gnocci and wine. it was delicious. perfect place for a romantic date.
author: Marie G.

description:
Went here for a group party. The staff was gracious and helpful and the atmosphere was inviting. 
The food was scrumptious!! I want more gnocchi! I would definitely come back.
author: jamie o.

description:
Best gnocchi in town. The polenta crab cake was way too salty and the lamb rib was overcooked. Smoked prosciutto pizza was just ok. 
called for a reservation 45mins beforehand and was seated promptly. Service was great. 
Would come back for the gnocchi!
author: Fanny L.

description: I dined here last night.  The food is very good.  I had a pizza and the mushroom gnocchi (is that how you spell it).  Both were better than I could make, let's put it that way.  The service was just okay, food took too long to come out of the kitchen, but all in all was a good meal.  Pricey though.  Also the tables are too close together.  Don't go here for an intimate meal as you sitting on top of your neighbor.
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description: Bf picked this place for our 6 years anniversary! It's really sweet and cozy place for a romantic dinner for 2! The workers are nice and the food is pretty good. However, I still can't justify 18 dollars for pasta that have no sauce, no cheese but just mushrooms and olive oil. The noodles were sticking together too so it had a doughy taste to it. The place can get really loud during dinner time. Their bread were delicious and I will be back just for the pizza!
author: Aylee G.

description: Pizza was ok. Food a little overpriced
author: Tiger H.

description: 1 star. They are horrible. The food is average. We ordered an over priced pizza along with calamari. Actually the calamari wasn't that bad. They sat us half an hour after our reservation. And charged us for the stupidest things without notifying us. I wouldn't recommend going here. I don't get easily upset, but the way I was treated made me absolutely furious.
author: Karli K.

description: My new favorite Italian restaurant.  The service was great and the food was even better
author: Al G.

description:
Second dinner at Vega last night in a month and it was super delicious! I had to yelp about it. 

If you want a small, cozy, Italian dinner, this is the place to go! 

The crust on the pizza is unbelievable, just like I like it, thin but not so thin it doesn't hold up if you fold your slice. 
The gnocchi is out of this world with pesto sauce, ugh, who could ask for anything more? 
Ravioli special last night was spinach and ricotta and made me want to get up and dance around it was so good. 
Panna Cotta is sweet and tart at the same time, great with sweet strawberry sauce. 
Homemade Limoncello that I want to bath in! 

I love this neighborhood gem! 
Dangerous that all we have to do it walk up the hill to get there. 
We need to make more of a habit of eating at Vega.

I loved the limoncello so much I told the owner and she let me try another one she is working on....I love that sort of interaction at small restaurants.
author: Katie S.

description:
I really love Vega. The owners are fabulous, friendly, and authentically Italian. Roman, I believe. 

My partner and I go almost weekly for our carb-load. We are both unapologetic Italia-philes. 

The pizzas are thin-crust and delicious. Very Roman. The pastas and entrees are great too. Recently, the menu was updated and my favorite (a basic housemade pasta with pomodoro sauce) was gone. Not to worry, they made it for me anyway!

We are welcomed with a smile and friendly, "Ciao, buona sera. Come siete?" They remember us and we feel like regulars. In this town of always new and trendy, it's a nice change of pace. Not that I don't love the hotspots too. 

One that note, be aware that this is a small busines. Sometimes, the service is a tad slow. It' di s italiano autenticamente!
author: Danielle L.

description: So so good. Tried several dishes- grilled calamari, prociutto stuffed with cheese, cappelini with crab and the gnocchi with sausage, mushrooms and truffle oil. All were delicious and I would eat any of them again happily. The calamari was perfectly grilled and not chewy which is so important. The gnocchi...the gnocchi. What a glorious combination! Next time I'm in SF, Vega is at the top of my list.
author: mary m.

description: Warm, intimate, romantic Italian spot but the food was only ok and the service was poor.  We ordered salad, mushroom/ truffle pizza and baked rigatoni and none of the dishes were standout.  The pizza needed more cheese.  For dessert we had an ice cream cookie sandwich and this was definitely yummy.
author: Elana R.

description: Get the Gnocchi with truffle oil! cozy, and delicious - a bit loud for all the kids that were dining that night but we were 4 louder adults drinking wine :-)
author: Sfgpgirl G.

description: We go out often and this place continues to be one the best values in sf . Very reasonsble prices and great food
author: Eugene C.

description:
YUM! and pretty affordable. $11 6 slice margherita pizza was pretty filling for me and my boyfriend, we didn't need dessert or appetizer. Truly delicious and tasty. 

Service was quick and friendly. Cute ambiance but a little dark as others have noted. They have a lot besides pizza on the menu so I can't wait to go back!
author: Latte Queen W.

description:
I love Neapolitan pizza and in San Francisco, Vega does it best. The whole package is just beautiful. Get the Margarita and you won't be disappointed. You will not want to share so make sure everybody gets their own!

The staff is always friendly and happy to help but if it takes a while for them to get to you... relax, drink your drink and be comforted by the fact that you are about to eat one of the best pizzas in SF!
author: Matt D.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this place. My wife and I are foodies and wine connouissiers, and Vega sets the standard for what a small Italian restaurant should be. Yes, it's small and in Bernal Heights and if you don't have a reservation, you can expect to wait a while for a table... and even if you do have a reservation, if it's super busy you might have to wait a bit. But,  you can get some wine while you wait, and once you're seated you will be very well taken care of. This is not one of those so-called five-star chain restaurants. This is a tiny "hole in the wall" family run place. It's not that big, and its reputation is such that you should expect it to be busy during peak periods, possibly with a line going out the door. The kitchen is large enough for about 3 chefs to work in and they can only put out so much food in a certain amount of time. 

My wife and I have been here several times now and each visit was excellent. If this place seems authentic, it's because it is! Vega, is the owner. She's there pretty much all the time and has an excellent staff supporting her. Each morning, her husband calls his mother in Italy to work out the day's specials, etc. All the pasta is hand-made, etc. There is no way to rush preparation of food this quality. It just takes dedication and patience. If you come here and it's crowded and noisy, that's a sign that they have kept their prices reasonable and the food delicious. Don't be discouraged, just hang in there and wait for a table and be glad they're not asking for twice as much money. They could easily do that and it would still be worth it. They keep the prices reasonable because we all deserve to be able to enjoy this food.

First: the wine. They offer an excellent selection of wines by the glass as well as by the bottle. If you're going by the glass, get the Sangiovese. Heck, even by the bottle, it's a good value. If you really want to splurge, go for a bottle of Brunello di Montalicino. Awesome stuff. 

We've had an appetizer called Involtini di Mare here, it's a wonderful combination of shrimp, mango, avocado, and smoked salmon. Get it. 

I really love the gnocci here. Gnocci is a potato dumpling style pasta, it's hand-rolled and always cooked to perfection here. Each bite is a bite of heaven. Having had it on my first visit (and it's one of their specialties), each time I come here, I struggle to avoid ordering it, so I can try something new.  There are two forms it comes in: "della casa", which is basically just the dumplings with sauce, or "alla boscaiola", which comes with mushrooms, (amazing) Italian sausage, and truffle oil.  Both are good, but the extra mushrooms and sausage push the second one slightly ahead in my preferences.

My wife similarly struggles with the braised pork ribs. They are so good, she can't order anything else.They are incredibly tender and seasoned perfectly, and it all just melts in your mouth. This comes with a polenta to die for!

The rigatoni is really excellent as well. I recommend you get this their meatballs, which are really tender and tasty. Absolutely delicious!

The fish specials are always fresh and cooked to perfection. We've had some really amazing scallops here, and scallops are very hard to do well. A poorly executed scallop will leave you never wanting them again. A properly cooked one will melt in your mouth and you will be in love! This place has the latter of the two.

Vega has my favorite Panna Cotta for dessert, of anywhere. It's creamy and delicious.  I have also tried the ice cream with espresso poured over it, and that's really good too. My wife says that the Tiramisu is priceless. They don't always have it on the menu, ask for it. It's the best one she has ever had, and she tries it in every high-end italian restaurant we go to. I concur.

Apparently, they are known for their pizza! The pizzas I have seen other people eating in here look really good, but the other food on the menu is so good, and I don't live nearby, there's a very good chance I will never get around to trying the pizza.

As a final note, Vega's husband has opened a restaurant across the street.  We have not yet had the opportunity to try it out, but I think we will be able to expect the same quality there.
author: Adam B.

description: A recent discovery but a happy one. Baked Penne is amazing, if you like wine go on a Wednesday any bottle is half price.
author: Alison F.

description: Food was sooooo good! You'll forget all about north beach once the food touches your lips. Staff was very impressive as well.
author: Lisa M.

description:
This place is a lovely little eatery.  The quality of the ingredients were excellent and the preparation was wonderful. 

We had the polenta crab cake, proscuitto-wrapped artichoke hearts, gnocchi with mushroom and Italian sausage, and speck and mozzarella di bufala pizza.  While the crab cake was an odd paring of flavors (something I wouldn't order again), the artichoke hearts and gnocchi were divine.  The pizza was decent with a wonderful crust, but rather bland from what I was expecting.  However, with the quality found in the other dishes, Vega is a place I will definitely recommend.
author: Rebekah C.

description:
I've known where bernal hights area is, but never step in there since I dont think there is nice restaurant.
I m totally wrong! really pretty little town has lots of lovely restaurants and shops! sorry bernal hights!
My husband and I decided to come here because their cute red decor seemed to invite us. Our inspiration was right! 
this little gem is really cozy, warm, friendly, the food is generous, tasty and reasonable price. especially their pasta was awesome! you should try gnocchi with mashroom cream sauce. Also we enjoyed some glass of house wine, just $5!
author: Spinof P.

description: I didn't eat here. We were 10 minutes late for our reservation and the guy (owner/manager?) was extremely rude, basically scolding us and telling us there was no way we'd get seated anytime soon. Our bad for being late, but his lost customer for being a jerk about it (I've lost all interest in eating there). Good thing Liberty Cafe is just across the street.
author: Rob M.

description: They forgot our food for 45 minutes. They actually forgot to put the order in in the kitchen, and as a result the food wasn't ready until a full hour after we ordered. And their version of trying to make good was to take five dollars off the bill. If this place couldn't rely on the fact that people in the neighborhood don't have a lot of options, they'd have closed. The food is fine, but it's not worth the price or the hassle.
author: Georgia F.

description:
What can I say.  We wanted to start with a bottle of red and a bottle of white and when we suggested the waiter choose, she immediately brought out a few tastes.  We landed on a brilliant Nero Di Avola and a falanghina that was soooo fresh and delicious.  On the food end of things we shared a fresh and lively salad as well as a salumi and cheese plate that was completely amazing.  We shared a pizza and the ever popular gnocchi and were not disappointed.  Interesting flavor combo's, fresh ingredients and perfect gnocchi!  

And for dessert, nothing could be finer than ice cream topped with espresso..heaven.  And to top it off, one of the owners, Vega, brought us a little dessert wine on the house..why?? I don't know but it too was delish!

eat here often!
author: Julian M.

description: Yum! Had the pizza with mushrooms and truffle oil. So good! The crust is just like in Italy! I use to live there and this places pizza is the real deal! Had the house Petit Sarah for $5. Fantastic! I love this place and want to try more of their menu. Definitely a place to come back to!
author: Louise M.

description: I love this place. It's intimate, has great food and wine list.  Anytime I'm craving Italian food, I only want to come here. The gnocchi is super yummy and same goes for their pizzas.  If you want a nice romantic night out, come here!
author: Kelly M.

description: Nice neighborhood Italian spot. Very good food and reasonably priced. Will be going back!
author: Richard R.

description: I was here a coupld of weeks ago.  They had Cinghiale (wild boar pasta)!  I have only had this in Italy as I've never seen it on a menu in the US previously.  The room is a bit quieter now with some changes in the dining room. But it remains extremely noisy in this place.  There were also several small children in this place the night we dined here. I would go more often for the food but it's just too noisy.  So 5 stars for the Cinghiale and 3 stars for the noisy dining room.  The wait staff is nice and friendly.
author: Marian P.

description:
Quaint italian eats
Pizza is fine, gnocchi rocks
"Eh" service costs star
author: Shannon N.

description:
My first Yelp review (how exciting) and I'm pleased that it's going to be a positive one.

My wife and I strolled through Bernal Heights for the first time last weekend and stumbled on this gem for lunch. We had visions of run-of-the-mill neighborhood Italian fare but we ended up with a well prepared and delicious meal that exceeded our expectations.

We shared a beef carpaccio starter that was great quality and well seasoned, followed by pizzas that were every bit traditional - sitting atop a wafer thin, crispy crust.

The wines were both tasty and reasonably priced. The Falanghina had a nice crispness and the Primitivo was robust but balanced.

The only (very slight) detractor was that our pizzas were ever so slightly delayed, but having enjoyed our starter and wine so much we barely noticed.

We'll be back again for sure!
author: Matt T.

description: Not impressed. I evaluate Italian restaurants by the basics, and in this case, the Margherita pizza was a bland dud; I don't cook and I could have done better. The chocolate mousse was tasty, though it was missing the freshly whipped cream. Service was a tad chilly.
author: Hella Stella Y.

description:
I don't normally write such a stellar review after only one visit, but everything about the experience last night was just unbelievably perfect I just have to.  The two owners even gave my date and I glasses of house-made limoncello on-the-house at the end of the meal... only because the waiter had overheard I live a close walk away.  I'm not one that's easily bribed, but that was just a special touch at the end of a very special evening.

I am very much a wine snob, but admittedly I know the least about Italian wines, and the list is pretty much all Italian.  However, it's not an overwhelming list and pretty easy to navigate with the waiter's assistance.  I discovered in conversation with the hostess that she was actually the owner of the Vino Rosso wine bar down the street which I had been to many times... so that explains the excellent wine list :).  We chose a Sangiovese riserva which was perfect for the meal.  To start, we had this salad of fresh, local dungeness crab meat with cucumber, avocado, endive, and tomatoes drizzled simply with garlic oil and black pepper.  The amount of crab on this appetizer was HUGE... which made my date and I very, very happy.  Next was a small thin crust pizza with rapini, sage sausage, garlic, buffalo mozzarella, and parmesan suggested by the hostess... simply amazing.  Then we moved on to pasta dishes - paparadelle with wild boar ragu and spaghetti a la carbonara, both of which were with house made pasta and perfectly spicy and rich.  Everything winded down with a shared chocolate mousse with strawberry sauce that was very light and airy and a very perfect close to the dinner.

This place very obviously recognizes that it's existence is dependent upon those of us in the neighborhood and it shows handsomely.  I'm a real big fan of restaurants that are constantly cognizant of their market and their guests and their needs.  This place won on all those counts hands down.  Perfect neighborhood restaurant that I will be going to again and again.
author: Chris P.

description: Excellent food and service. I came from out of town and I wish there was one near me! The gnocchi, pizza, and salads were amazing:)
author: Amanda A.

description:
We dined here on 10/22, but were not credited our 1000 point OpenTable reservation.  We were on time and met all the requirements and THEN SOME of receiving the points, but they marked us a "No Show."  :(  VERY BAD.  I've now called and emailed Vega 5 times, spoke w/ the owner Vega one time who PROMISED to correct and rectify the reporting error w/ OT, yet my OT account STILL nearly 2 months later remains scarred with this infraction now, and NONE of the points were ever received.  Calling again this week, I've never received a return phone call as to what is going on, and no apology.  Despite being in the neighborhood, I will never patronize this place again, and urge others NOT to either.
The food and service was nothing special...actually, their hostess and girl, Rachel, who answered the phone the last time were complete ignorant/arrogant snots (much as others here have mentioned along w/ really annoying noisy acoustics...so BEWARE!)...so I guess, I'm not surprised that the hostess marked us a no show when we were there.   No rest. should EVER employ someone to receive diners that makes them feel like shit when they walk in...she should be FIRED, STAT.  Get your act together and start managing better, Vega.
author: Dana H.

description:
If you've been to Tuscany and wondered why you can't find *real* Italian food in the US, you have to go to Vega.  I am so thrilled this restaurant has opened in our neighborhood.  We've been many times and the food is stellar.  Took 2 friends there last night and they were blown away too.  The owner is lovely and the whole place has such heart and soul.  

[The old place, Valentina's, was owned by a really nice woman but the food was not good, in my opinion.  It was the kind of Italian food you get in North Beach.  In other words, mostly awful and Americanized.]

Vega has great wine, fantastic pizza and some delicious and original appetizers.  I've had the polenta and lamb a few times and it's becoming my favorite. And it's hard to find affogatto (ice cream covered in espresso!) but they  have it here. Everything we've tried has been great.  And the wine bar they own down the street is great too.  Some buffala mozarella brought over from Italy that made me want to cry happy tears of cheese.

One of my favorite new restaurants!
author: Darla W.

description:
Great local place, small room but not too noisy.
Grilled calimari with white beans! YEA!
Grilled seabass. Double YEA!
Will be back next time in town.
author: Al M.

description: We had the brocollini and salcicca pizza, the pork ribs and polenta and a side of asparagus and it was all delicious.  Even tho the place was packed (bottle of wine for half-price on Tuesdays), the wait staff was gracious and efficient. We love this neighborhood place and did I mention the half-price bottles of wine on Tuesday.  We had the Abruzzo de Montepulciano Riserva and it was superb! (and we took home what we couldn't drink and eat).
author: Elaine E.

description: WOW! I put this place on the same level as Cotogna, F&W and Beretta! Super cozy romantic environs with just a hint of truffle rolling out from the kitchen. The pizzas were cooked to perfection. We tried the Porcini and the caprese (which is really just a very good Margarita!) The Paparadelle with mushroom had a real homemade bite to it. I am an admitted SOMAphile, but I will definitely travel back to Bernal Heights again and again for this place! Oh, great Italian Wine selection as well.
author: glenn w.

description: AMAZING! The food is so good that you want to curl up in it and never leave. Save room for the amazing ice cream sandwich, I don't even like ice cream but it was so good I never wanted wanted it to end.
author: Prestin B.

description:
My wife had just raved about this place before so I wanted to bring the family to try it and I--WE--can't wait to return again.  We started with a pizza appetizer that was incredibly crisp, fresh and delicious.  I say "crisp" because it was on a thin crust base that will quite crunch and good.  

Every body like their salad but felt they could have put a wee bit more dressing.  Don't get me wrong, they were great.  The next time I will ask for some on the side. 

I had the gnocchi with sausage that was so good I was not giving up a bite.   My boys had the ribs with polenta and my wife had the duck.  The boys weren't sharing either their meals.  My wife liked her duck, but didn't give it the same kind of star ratings we gave it.  Our waitress  was really nice and knowledge and the owner stop to asked up how we like everything right when we were leaving.  

That said, the food ambiance and staff made for this an enjoyable experience.  We will be returning again.  

ALSO:  The place is small.  So reserve ahead of time.  We came in at 4:30 on a Sunday.  The place was empty when we arrived but filled up quickly.
author: D M.

description: The manager/owner is horrific!! He was so rude to me and I just so happened to walk in when he was reprimanding his chef! I felt so bad for him, Because of his complete inhumane actions I will never go back. I feel for those who work in the kitchen. They have the least pay and the least respect. And the way the owner completely humiliated his chef in front of many guest makes me so disgusted. I will never go back and ask all yelpers to not patronize this horrific establishment!
author: Bobbie M.

description: I am so into this place.  Went for the first time last month and have already been back three times.  The broccolini and sausage pizza is out of control.
author: Jim M.

description: Came here again last night with a friend, and the rigatoni dish hit the spot once again.  Service could have been better, hence the 4 stars.
author: Linh D.

description: Friend took me here for a Tues nite dinner. Yummy salad, Delicious Pizza with fresh Buffalo Mozzarella and Heirloom Tomatoes =) Yummm.... and a very good Red Wine we picked out as the menu said it was "assertive and intense" -- yes it was =)
author: Amber F.

description:
We were big fans of Valentina's, and it's a shame she got sick and had to sell the business.

We've been to what is now Vega (finally renamed early this year) three times now, and I feel like I can compare the two.

Similarly to Valentina's, there have been some initial consistency problems.  I guess this is the nature of the restaurant business, but we haven't hit two bad nights in a row, so let's assume Vega is working it out.

The service seems a little better across the board.  Valentina had a couple of good servers, but she had bad luck with several as well.  Last night's service at Vega was top notch.  

Vega did make some weird choices, like charging for olive oil with the bread because it was really good olive oil.  People must have barked at that because last night we got some without asking.

I'd say Vega has been mostly very good.  The pecan-crusted halibut rocks.  The mushroom and sausage gnocchi knocked the socks off my friend's first visit.  Last night I had the lobster linguini special and it was disappointing... sauce and noodles were fine, but there was only half of a small lobster tail on it, the meat in it was slightly overcooked, and the dish quantity was too small.  Not good for $19.

Salads and wine have both been satisfying. Also, they make a fine machiatto, which is not so easy to find these days, despite the proliferation of coffee shops.
author: Danny H.

description: Wednesday is half off bottles of wine... And I must say the food is exceptional- fresh calamari, broccoli rabe pizza ( WAY better than it sounds!) and chicken saltimboca - all excellent, and they set a table just for us even though the restaurant was full. We will definitely be back:)
author: Spunky M.

description: When I make yet another attempt to find a decent pizza around here I always start with the Margherita and this one was quite good. Not Brooklyn good, but defintely Bay Area good-excellent. The crust is a bit too thin and has a cracker-like feel around the edges, but otherwise a very good effort. Also had  some greens and the whole meal was only $21 - a nice bargain.  Service was attentive and it seems here that you will be taken care of by anyone who is on the floor.
author: George S.

description: We made reservations for 8:30 on a Wednesday night. We we're seated at 9:15. it was very busy and people were waiting out front . The owner/manager offered each of us a free glass of wine while we waited. Overall, the service was okay but the food was really good.  Had the Sea Bass and friends had the Nocchi. Even after waiting and ok service, would go back for the food. Really good.
author: Michael M.

description: A terrific moderately priced neighborhood Italian restaurant.  I had the baked rigatoni with sausage. Wow. I couldn't stop eating it.  And they have a very good inexpensive house red wine.  Can't wait for my next visit to try some other entrees.
author: Leonard G.

description: This place was fantastic! I took my partner here for her birthday and was nervous because I had never been and birthdays are a big deal. We ended up at the table by the window which was amazing! Bernal is my favorite neighborhood in SF and we had a great street view for people watching. I ordered some wine which was excellent and the food was exceptional. The place is small so it gets pretty loud but I love the cozy feel and the service was really good. The bread and olive oil were both so fresh and reminded me of when I lived in Italy! She had the chicken and I had the lamb and both were really good. We had an amazing experience and will definitely be back!
author: Morgan M.

description: the baked rigatoni is off the hook and the wine was delicious and not to expensive. It's small and cozy without feeling claustrophobic, the wait staff is helpful but not all up in your business. i will definately return.
author: Lily S.

description:
Let me be clear, my poor rating is for the service.  We had the same woman who was hostess/server that others have mentioned.  She became very annoyed when we asked for a couple minutes to decide on our order.  No surprise when she asked how everything was and I said the food was wonderful, but the noise excrutiating.  She replied with a deadpan expression saying, "That's not under my control".  Well then, who the f*** does? "Kids should be seen and not heard" is not the motto here.  Don't get me wrong, as I don't have a problem with kids eating out.  I have a problem when 5 kids sitting at the large party behind us, who have not been taught how to behave in restaurants.  The adults in the party had to scream to be heard over their kids who were screaming most of the time.  It seemed that this party may have been friends of the hostess, which would explain the spineless response.
Too bad, as it was one of the best Carbonara dishes I've had.  Don't step foot into this place on Tuesdays unless you have your ear plugs...it's kids day.
author: Arlene C.

description: Yummy but elegant comfort food in an intimate, friendly environment.  This is a neighborhood Italian joint done right.  Pizzas are very good (but not great, as they tend to be a little soggy in the middle).  However they make up for it by offering some great options, such as an egg and arugula on top.  I'm not a gnocchi person, but my girlfriend loves theirs.  Their pastas are delicious, as is the house salad.  We love this place.
author: Ritik C.

description: Cute neighboorhood spot! Great service. Food was ok. I expected more.
author: Joyce M.

description:
Disclaimer: This review is mostly based off take out service.

Last Saturday night my girlfriend and I were feeling lazy and felt like staying in, ordering a pizza and watching a good movie so we decided to try out Vega.  We ordered a simple Margarita pizza and a side of the polenta.  Since we live a few miles away we decided to order ahead so we would not have to wait.  First call... no answer.  Ok, they are most likely busy.  I will try back in a few minutes.  A few minutes later success! We placed our order with a pleasant women on the phone and she informed us that the food would be ready in 25 minutes.  We wait the full 25 minutes at our home and take off the get the food.  Ten minutes later we are at Vega.  I step in to let the hostess know I had called an order in.  She looks puzzled and goes to the kitchen for confirmation.  When she comes back she asks me if I got the Margarita pizza and polenta and I agree.  To my disappointment I then can see my food is just being prepared right behind her, 35 minutes after initially ordering.  The hostess did not offer me anything to drink or a seat like she did for the other patrons waiting right next to me.  I waited another 10-15 minutes outside until my food was done and given to me and at that point had been double the estimated time given to me, for thin pizza.  We got back home and were pleasantly surprised with the food.  The pizza was very thin, light and delicious.  The sauce and cheeses tasted very fresh.  The polenta was good as well,  nothing really special.  Even though the pizza was good I will not be returning because of the service and with plenty of other good thin crust pizza places in the Bay Area.
author: Shawn B.

description:
We had excellent dining experience.  My small family of three had a Great Dinner Experience and Great Service.  I will drive 40 miles again from San Ramon to go eat here.  The gnocchi with sausage and truffle oil was excellent.  The staff was friendly, the House Red Wine is a Petite Syrah which is an excellent choice and it is only $5 per glass.  I left behind my coat on my seat when I left.  The owner ran down the street with my coat to find me...  :-)

The place is small.  Hope and pray that there is no large loud group when you go there.  During our last visit, there was a group with one woman who was not only dominating all conversation on her table, she was so loud, she was dominating all audio spectrum in the restaurant, or at least it sounded so in the small dining room.  After they left...  whew, we could talk to each other.

I hope the owner/s will find a way to accommodate small families and couples who wants a quiet dining experience.  Perhaps some two and three seat tables in a quiet corner or another room.
author: Philip C.

description:
Wow, this place is incredible.  The food is so fresh and everything tasted great.

The fresh dungeness crab appetizer tasted like it was brought from ocean straight to my plate.  The fish of the day happened to be a rock cod, which was the freshest fish I've had since being in Hawaii 4 months ago.  

The baked rigatoni tasted even better than the version my Italian Grandmother used to make me when I was growing up in NY.  

I highly recommend this place.  Even the olive oil was some of the best i've had.  

Make a reservation because this place is small and fills up quickly.
author: Chris R.

description: Unbelievable food, wine, and service. Incredible! We will certainly be back.
author: Kara H.

description: Website says open til 10:30 on Fri/Sat.  Don't believe it.   I arrived at 10:15, after working all day and evening, running out of the house to get there on time, and the maitre and head waitress were sitting eating their dinner, but told me kitchen was closed, no offer of a salad, glass of wine, anything.  I've been a customer for years, but no more.
author: cp d.

description:
Delicious pasta coupled with a good wine selection (1/2 price bottles on Wednesdays!).  Vega is a cozy place set under a leafy tree on cute and up-and-coming Cortland street.   I like their pasta dishes a bit more than the pizzas (have to agree with the reviewer who mentioned a cracker-like crust).   

Anyway, give it a try and you'll likely return.
author: workingstiff f.

description:
I've been dying to try this place, when you peek in the window,  it's visions of the perfect date night given that this place is small, intimate and lit with candles. Alas, I had a date to bring! It's so adorable, simple but the lighting was perfect for the stormy night. Food was delicious. We started out with the house salad, it was so good, parmesan, grapefruit and the perfect amount of dressing. I had the capellini with crab and there was the perfect amout of crab. My date had this baked cheesy goodness.
We finished with meal with the Lemon Pancotta, perfectly set, perfectly lemony and not too sweet topped with strawberry sauce. A delight. 
The only reason I am not giving this 5 stars, I just felt like the waitress could of been a little more sweet and not so distracted since it was not all the busy anyways..I can say I will go back again and again. Especially since I have not tried the pizza's yet! YUM!
author: Deandra B.

description: Amazing Italian food - don't miss their crab spaghetti or any one of their pizzas! Just remember to make a reservation before you go.
author: Al K.

description:
"I love this place"
"Can there be any more mushrooms on this pizza? Amazing!"
"Wow, this wine goes perfectly with the ragu"
"If I close my eyes, I can easily imagine that we're back in Italy"

These were some of the words coming out of our mouths (whenever we had a moment to speak while scarfing down the delicious food at Vega).

We randomly happened upon this place while scoping out our new apt in Bernal.  Lucky for us, it was 1/2 price bottle Wednesday.

Even luckier for us, the food is awesome, authentic, and well-priced.  Portions are plentiful, staff are very friendly, and the owner, Giuseppe, welcomed us personally to the neighborhood with a complimentary panna cotta for dessert.  Oh, we'll be back, my friend.  

On to the food:  

We shared a pappardelle with boar ragu and a mushroom pizza.  Both were prepared expertly.  Pappardelle is homemade and of perfect texture.  Pasta to sauce ratio is spot-on (not sopping in sauce).  Ragu tasted great - not too salty and hint of acidity.

Pizza is thin and crispy, loaded with toppings.  Not true neapolitan pizza, but they don't claim that either.  Hint of truffle rounded out this excellent pizza.

We can't wait to go back to try the other food, including the secondi (saw a fish entree that looked great).

Finally, the Italian-focused wine list is sized right:  Not too big, but enough choices to pair with all the different types of food.  We had a Cannonau di Sardegna, and it was a good pairing with both of our dishes.  

Can't wait till our next visit!
author: Richard K.

description: Oh gosh.  Well Vega is certainly hit or miss.  But since what I ordered was a total miss...I gotta give it 3 stars (the Rigatoni Al Forno was a 5 star dish).  I got the pizza - one with mushrooms (pizza al funghi) and one with prosciutto (pizza speck). Uhhh...they were both really really bad. We took them home and didn't eat them.  I know you guys will think - well that's REAL Italian pizza - but it wasn't the no sauce or thin crust that bothered me. It was the NO flavor.  None.  Whatsoever.  So bland tasting.  In sum - get the pasta -- it was delicious!!
author: Alph G.

description: What a great spot - excellent customer service and exquisite food.  The ribs over polenta are just ridiculous, and the mushroom and truffle oil pizza is indescribably tasty.  I have been known to bowl over little kids and their moms strolling on Cortland Street in my haste to get to this restaurant.  They do great takeout; the food doesn't suffer.  They also have 1/2 price wine on Wednesdays, I believe.  Finally, great atmosphere - small, dark, and intimate.  A gem.
author: Chauncey C.

description: My best friend took me here for my Birthday dinner last night.  He made reservations on open table, we were about 10 minutes late but no problems.  The atmosphere was cheerful and uplifting, the food was delicious, the service was prompt, courteous and delightful.  And if you like a perfect sized dessert, try the homemade ice cream sandwich.  OMG !!!!, not too filling but......wow good.  Seems like they also have quite a loyal following of customers.  That says a lot about a business.  To top it off, they were filming an episode of  "check please" while we ate, so we got ourselves on T.V.  Careful with large groups though.  It's cozy and can be kind of loud inside when the night gets going.
author: Michael R.

description: Very good pizza. But it's not Neapolitan pizza... it's Roman. They aren't the same, with the latter arriving in Rome even over only the past couple of generations. They didn't change the place much from the old Valentina Ristorante (which was more Ligurian): tight quarters, small tables (seating for 32), loud diner noise. The gnocchi aren't light like some places and are more the heavier potato variety, but they are excellent. Service is quite good too. Let's hope this one stays longer than Valentina.
author: Teddy B.

description:
I was in the Bay Area several weeks ago.  The day after my wife and I arrived was a Sunday and I had some free time to visit with a friend who lives in Bernal Heights.  We walked up the hill from his place to grab a quick bite to eat and he gave me the choice of The Liberty Cafe or Vega.  I didn't know jack about either place.  I had never heard of either.  I chose Vega.

The restaurant was a little tight, but that could be that we are both over 6'5" tall.  The server was attentive without being overbearing and we were able to place our orders relatively quickly.  Both my friend and I ordered the Pizza  Capricciosa which was advertised in the menu with tomato sauce, mozzarella, prosciutto, artichoke, mushrooms, egg.

I had never ordered a pizza with prosciutto or egg on it before, so I didn't know quite what to expect.  It did take a while for our food to arrive and I started salivating from the aroma emanating from the kitchen.  I was preoccupied with my conversation, so I didn't particularly care that the food took a little extra longer to arrive.  When it did arrive, oh boy!  It was pizza perfection!  The crust was thin, crisp, tender and perfectly charred around the edges.  The prosciutto was tissue paper thin.  The egg yolk broke and made a tasty ooey gooey mess.  The artichoke was pleasantly tart.  I am a big guy, so the relatively small thin crust pizza only roused my appetite without properly bedding it back down, but had I added a salad or dessert, I don't think this would have been the case.  To make things even better, my friend picked up the tab at the end of the meal.  I REALLY owe him for this one.

Every time my wife and I visit the Bay Area, I am amazed at the little hole-in-the-wall restaurants that one can find if one only has a smidgen of adventure and just walks in.  I will definitely return for many more meals at Vega!
author: Brian S.

description: Wow, what a great find! My wife and I were looking for a simple italian meal on a Sat night. Nothing fancy, just a nice plate of pasta and glass of wine. Vega delivered that and more. Service was fast and pleasant, not rushed. Never felt like we were waiting for server. Both the salad and pasta dishes we had were fantastic as were the wine selections. Vega is the type of restaurant that every neighborhood should have. Great food, atmosphere and reasonably priced.
author: John B.

description: Service: superior...friendly and totally accommodating.  Place: Bernal Heights...fun, different and another kind of SF urban... The food choices are varied, well made and the pizzas are lovely, thin-crusted and immaginative.  The Pannacotta was marred by a lemon topping which made it more like a Lemon meringue pie filling than the pannacotta I was hoping for. One miss ain't bad.
author: Victor M.

description: A neighborhood gem, with charming italian /american owners. We love everything there, from their thin crust pizzas, to their mussels pasta and delicious rigatoni al forno. Do not miss their panna cotta - one of the best I've ever eaten.
author: S. P.

description: The only reason I go to this place is that it is within walking distance of my home. If you know italian food, it's mediocre. Otherwise you might think it's good. The atmosphere is nothing special, the service is spotty when they are busy. The wine selection is good. The pizza with Brocoli Rabe and grilled calamari are good, the meatballs are awful (truly awful - meat tastes like it is from a chef boy r dee, sauce tastes like campbells tomato soup). It's usually very busy and incredibly noisy so not sure what's wrong with me. Three points instead of two because when we mentioned that we didn't like the meatballs very much, the waiter said thanks for telling him and brought us a free dessert.
author: Paul F.

description:
We love Vega. Started eating there about a year ago and it's one of our favorites to go. We've been several times and have enjoyed ourselves each visit. 

Kind of reminds me of Beretta, but much lower key & neighborhoody. Alternatively, a bit like Pasta Pomodoro, but better food & again - more neighborhoody. One of our favorites with kids.

I really like the people who work there, the food, the cozy atmosphere. Would recommend it for dinners with or without kids. Great pizza!
author: Carl B.

description: These folks know how to cook!  Excellent food, wine list, service. The squid with white beans, yikes it's good. Fish ditto, pizza yup. Wednesdays 1/2 off wine. Baked rigatoni? Oh yes.
author: tom t.

description: Got a chance to check out Vega w/ a restaurant.com certificate.  Wine selection and duck pate was ok.  The ambience was nice.  Service was odd - gal waiting on us seemed to be having bad day... If I needed to meet someone at a wine bar and was in bernal, then I might go back to Vega.  As for value, it was only ok, with the gift certificate.  Otherwise, it's a bit pricey for what you get.
author: FoodJunkie S.

description: This has got to be the best hole-in-the-wall I have discovered in years. Friendly service, oustanding food, excellent ambiance. I came here with some friends about 2 weeks ago (they go there weekly, at least) and I'm still thanking them to turning me on to this place. I want to say that maybe a flashlight is needed to read the menu but even the lighting (or lack thereof) just adds to the charm of this Bernal Heights restaurant.
author: Scott C.

description:
This place does one thing exceptionally well...cooking food. (i guess thats what you want in a restuarant!) The food was absolutely wonderful - the gnocchi was as close as you can get to my family recipe! 
Unfortunately the service was terrible. We made a reservation for 6:45  (I had wanted 7 but there were no openings) We didn't get seated until 7:10 - I feel a Seinfeld reference coming on... Thankfully the host had offered us wine while we waited - I only wish he was there for when we sat down. After watching the two waiters walk by us 3 times each over a period of 15-20 minutes, I was about ready to either flag someone down or eat the napkin. Finally we got a server...without having to result to drastic measures.
The lack of communication between staff is what is dropping the stars - I ordered a glass of wine from one server but it never came...I eventually had to order it a second time (no apology).
The food was fantastic so I would definitely consider returning. My only hope is that they hire an additional waiter and/or fix their customer service.
author: Elisse S.

description: After a heinous night that involved emergency rooms and desperate calls to one's parents, getting a top-notch, healthy feast was a welcome relief.  We had the Insalatta Della Casa - delish!!  The Bufalata - also fantastic and the eggplant was sliced perfectly thin and cooked to perfection.  The pizza with mushrooms and truffle oil was superb!  I will definitely be back.
author: Winged F.

description: I love the casa salad.  Its my favorite, its so refreshing and there is a lot of it too.  I have had the baked rigatoni and it was SO filling and very tasty.  The meatballs were very good.  I had a margarhita pizza which was very tasty.  I'll go back again and again.  I like the wait staff, they are very informative and friendly, not too pushy or aloof.
author: Dana M.

description:
Outstanding.  We started with delicious wine (a Zinfandel that tasted chocolatey and berry-y as described).  I had the chicken breast sautéed in a white wine reduction sauce, Boyfriend CJ had the gnochhi with italian sausage and mushrooms, both were heavenly.  Perfect wine, best dessert I've had all year - chocolate mousse with slightly sweetened whipped cream and raspberry sauce that was tart so as to perfectly balance out the sweetness of the chocolate mousse and whipped cream....PERFECT. CJ's summation quote: "It should be a crime to eat food this good."  Seriously exceptional food, very reasonably priced considering.  

And yes, lovely romantic setting.

OH NO! I almost forgot about the DELICIOUS insalata rica! Scrumptious goat cheese with raisins, candied walnuts (made strongly consider incorporating candied walnuts into my daily life), spinach, and a nice, light vinaigrette dressing
author: Laura A.

description: As good as and in some respects even better than Delfina. Off the boat delicious and delightful Italian. Really hit the spot!
author: Denise D.

description: This place is LEGIT!!! My family went here for a birthday party and let me tell you every single dish we ordered was beyond words. I don't normally give 5 stars nor write a good review after only one visit but they had me at our appetizer. The menu has a great variety of everything and it is all worth a try. I also love that it is a cute little place owned by an acutal italian couple. They do a great job of walking around to make sure your meal is fab and making you feel right at home. We can't wait to go back and try all the other stuff on the menu. I suggest you make rezi b/c this place fills up fast.
author: Sam D.

description:
I went here on a date last night and I feel like it was mixed overall... 3.5 stars

Pros:
I liked where it's located. Parking was relatively easy (compared to some other parts of the city, like the Castro). 
I liked the menus...they were in a protective sheet of plastic and easy to read...I'm lame and like stuff like that
They had one of those double doors like they have in cottages (the one where it's split in half with a bottom and a top). It's very quaint
VERY good service. I accidentally and retardedly burned my thumb on a candle that I tried to steal to our table and the waitress we had, MANDY, who is very amazing was very attentive. I loved her. She alone earned this place 2 stars
The margherita pizza was very good. Super super thing crust and great flavors. The price was pretty Ok as well. I enjoyed it a lot. 

Cons:
Some of the things that were prices I felt like shouldnt have been priced that way (i.e. the calamari)
The calamari wasn't fried that much at all...in fact it was sauted. Not that I necessarily had a problem with it being sauted, but it was kind of rubbery and when I think calamari, I think fried. The dish was also served on a bed of beans which was kind of weird to me...
The bread was SUPER SALTY. Also their Pizza Speck. I dont know what they were doing, but man, that stuff would have given me a kidney stone if I kept eating it. Not sure what was up with that, but very very salty. I didnt end of eating a full mini-slice of bread or more than 1-2 slices of Pizza Speck which was disappointing
It was kind of cramped inside, and maybe because it was Friday night and what not, but I felt very cramped and it got kind of loud at certain points and it was hard for me to hear...or I'm getting old
The chairs were super rickety. To the point where I felt like if I moved too much, I'd break it...they should invest in tightening the screws or something b/c they were hella flimsy

Overall I may go back if I was in the area. A great  venue, but super salty menu for me. But the staff was excellent and I may go back just for them :)
author: Dustin H.
